John Smith wrote:
> --- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>  > No, I had lost the context of the discussion. I
>  > would use DbUnit or the
>  > ORM, whichever was simpler. In your case, I'd use
>  > the ORM.
>  >
>  > But, even better, I'd use a fake (not a mock!) Data
>  > Repository layer
>  > when testing Business Logic without worrying about
>  > where in particular
>  > the data comes from.
> 
> I agree. But what do you tell about integration
> testing? Some bugs will never show up if only mock
> objects are used. How do you catch them? Chapter 13
> doesn't seem to address our needs for integration
> testing.

It's true that we need Collaboration Tests (end-to-end, integration, 
whatever size they are) to find some defects, but that doesn't mean we 
ought to rely on them.

I recently added a little description of my approach to 
c2.com/cgi/wiki?AbstractTestCases, but I need to write more about it. 
Someday.

> You only mention FIT very shortly in your book. Is
> this the ultimate solution for integration testing?

No, because there is no such thing.

Fit is an excellent way to write customer-facing tests as well as 
data-driven programmer tests.

> What do you think about TestNG? I see that you don't
> mention it in your book.

I have never used TestNG; however, based on what I have seen, read and 
what Cedric has told me, I would use TestNG mostly to add tests to 
Legacy Code (any code I'm afraid to change) when TestNG's 
integration-test-related features would be useful. I would generally 
look for ways to refactor the codebase to be able to use Isolation Tests 
(one object at a time) most of the time.

> What do you say about test dependencies? In your book
> I only found a solution for ensuring that the tests
> are executed in a special order. But what about "skip
> test y if test x failed"? It reminds me of our batch
> programs: run batch y (which depends on results of
> batch x) only if batch x succeeded. Is there an addon
> for this for JUnit or a small and simple solution? Or
> should it not be done? In a way I agree with the
> author of TestNG that it would be nice to see 1 test
> passed, 1 test failed, 24 tests skipped instead of 1
> test passed and 25 tests failed.

This is one reason I'd use TestNG, but as an intermediate solution. Test 
interdependence is a design smell as well as making 
testing-as-fault-finding less effective/more annoying. I would want to 
refactor away from interdependent tests, then decide whether those tests 
need to move from TestNG to JUnit. From what I can tell, probably not.
